Hi there! Over the past ten weeks, I've been familiarizing myself with the nature that is my backyard. I recorded my thoughts and feelings, taking photographs along the way. I've found it to be a pleasant and educational experience. Being able to connect with nature reduces that isolation that many of us are feeling during the COVID-19 pandemic. If you are reading this, I hope my field journal helps you gain an appreciation for the little pockets of life around us.
Continue

Main Observation: Jujube Tree

This tree is a jujube tree. I only recently learned the name for it. In Vietnamese we call it trái táo tàu. A direct translation for that is Chinese apple. When ripe, the burnt red fruit it produces every year is succulent and sweet. Since we are in spring, I recorded overall changes in the tree every one to two weeks.

  • April 3, 2020

    All Bark

    The deformed twisting pattern of this tree’s branches caught my eye. It looks completely dead; there is no trace of green on it at all. Spine-like twigs protrude from the thicker branches. I saw a large crow land on the tip of the tallest branch. If it were an overcast day, this might have been an intimidating, almost sinister sight. But it’s a temperate seventy degrees and the sun is shining.

  • April 15, 2020

    First Leaves

    The jujube tree is starting to grow leaves. They appear in little clusters of about 5-10 leaves. It's crazy how fast this occurred. It has been a little less than two weeks since I last paid attention to it, when the tree was completely barren.

  • April 25, 2020

    More Leaves

    There is a noticeable difference in the amount of leaves between this time and last time. The leaves are about 2-3 inches long, every part of it a vibrant green. They continue to grow in clusters near each other. This might be hard to notice because the tree is getting more dense, but the clusters remain.

  • May 2, 2020

    More and More Leaves

    My only comment is that much of my observations today seem similar to last week. There are more of the skinnier green branches coming off from the main brown branch, however. The leaves grow mostly off of these green branches.

  • May 16, 2020

    Cloudy Days Ahead

    The weather is overcast today. We've been cycling through weeks of hot and cold weather. There's even more leaves on the tree. It's slightly weird how the leaves are growing from the trunk near the bottom of the tree. Apparently, different cultivars have physically different growth patterns, so our tree possibly looks normal.

  • May 29, 2020

    Buds and Blooms

    It's starting to look more like a bush than a tree...the leaves are growing so close to the bottom that they conceal the trunk. I took a closer look, and there are some buds on the branches. A few of them bloomed into flowers. The flowers aren't very big; they must be around 1 cm in diameter. No fruit yet, although quick research tells me that jujubes have a relatively long flowering and fruiting period that extends all the way to fall. I wouldn't be surprised if we didn't get fruit until later in the summer.

Aloe Vera

Aloe Vera

This is one of the few plants I think is essential for every household. Though they have a spiky exterior, they have a cool and soothing interior. I frequently use slices of aloe vera for sunburns, cooking oil burns, any type of burn. These succulents pretty much always look like this green color, so they're very hard to kill, that's for sure. It's spring time now, but even during the winter, I've never had them die.

  • Fun Fact: Don't be fooled by sugary aloe vera drinks you find in stores, raw aloe vera has a very bitter taste.

Weeds

???

I'm still not sure what these are called, but I thought the purple and green weeds growing out of the concrete made for a cool image. I've never really given much thought to weeds before, so I enjoyed trying to find small things in nature. I think this really shows the tenacity of life, how it tries to survive even in places it shouldn't be able to. Although I'm sure my dad doesn't appreciate this. He is always telling us to go weed our yard.

Spearmint

Mentha spicata

Spearmint grows surprisingly easy in large patches. The mint leaves have an interesting rough texture to them. Two leaves emerge from the same spot of the stem. Going upwards, each successive pair of leaves is perpendicular to the one before it, slowly becoming smaller and smaller. I actually don't enjoy the taste of these raw leaves, but I do like mint flavor in most other cases.

  • Fun fact: Native spearmint is used to flavor toothpaste and dental hygiene products, whereas Scotch spearmint has a milder, more pleasant taste and is used in chewing gum and candies.

Red-eared slider

Trachemys scripta elegans

I found a red-eared slider turtle in my backyard. It gets its name from the small red stripe around its ears. Based on its size, I'm guessing it is 5+ years old. However, my family has no idea how it got there. We have no water nearby, and our backyard is completely fenced off. I know that some varieties of turtles can live on land, such as this one. The turtle partially buried itself underground after we found it, which is how I discovered that they do this when they are frightened. It still begs the question, was this turtle always here?

  • Fun Fact: They are the world's most commonly traded reptile. Because they can live up to 30 years and inflict painful bites when mature, many irresponsible owners release them, causing them to now be considered an invasive species.

Mourning Dove

Zenaida macroura

4/28: A dove built a nest outside of our house! It is nested by our front door. My mom discovered it while sweeping and wondering where all the twigs on the floor came from. There was also a small broken egg on the floor, maybe the size of a golf ball. We are just leaving it alone for now.

5/22: Two baby birds hatched! My family isn't sure if this is when they were first born, but today is when we first noticed them. To me, they definitely look too big to be newly hatched, but I'm not too knowledgeable about that. They look a lot different than the mother dove. They are a much darker gray.

  • Fun fact: The bird is a strong flier, capable of speeds up to 55 mph.

Queen palm

Syagrus romanzoffiana

My family has 3 queen palms in our backyard. I'd estimate that they are somewhere around 20-30 feet tall. There are some palm fruits growing in a long bunch near the top of the tree. The palm fruits look similar in appearance to a bunch of grapes.

I think that palm trees are the quintessential Southern California tree. I always picture beaches or fancy streets lined with palm trees.

  • Fun Fact: The Queen Palm is native to southern Brazil (as are many Syagrus), northern Argentina, Paraguay and Uraguay. There it tends to grow in lowland areas or on small mountain ranges.
